title: Signals Intelligence
description: Signals Intelligence (SIGINT) encompasses interception, analysis, and exploitation of electronic signals. This section covers SDR platforms, signal identification, RF emitter analysis, and direction finding techniques for small team operations.

content.text: Signals Intelligence (SIGINT) is the interception, analysis, and exploitation of electronic signals for intelligence purposes. It involves monitoring and deciphering communication signals, including voice, data, and other electronic transmissions, to gather information about adversaries, threats, or targets of interest.

Small teams can effectively leverage Software-Defined Radios (SDRs) along with online resources like the Signal Identification Wiki (sigidwiki.com) to enhance their SIGINT capabilities. The combination of affordable hardware and specialized software enables meaningful collection operations without massive budgets traditionally associated with signals intelligence.
SIGINT Categories

SIGINT divides into two primary categories. Communications Intelligence (COMINT) focuses on intercepting and analyzing communications between parties, whether voice, text, or data. Electronic Intelligence (ELINT) focuses on non-communication emissions such as radar systems, navigation beacons, and unintentional emanations.

rows: Voice radio, digital messaging, data links

content.text: The Intelligence Cycle

SIGINT collection follows the intelligence cycle: planning and direction, collection, processing, analysis, and dissemination. Before deploying collection assets, define your intelligence requirements. What do you need to know? What signals might answer those questions? What frequencies and locations should you monitor?

content.title: Passive Collection Advantage
content.text: SIGINT collection is inherently passive. You receive electromagnetic energy that others transmit without transmitting yourself. This provides significant operational security advantages: no emission for adversaries to detect, no signal to direction-find, and no indicator of your presence. The only requirement is placing your receiver where the target signals can reach it.

Software Defined Radio (SDR) implements radio functions in software rather than hardware. Traditional radios use fixed circuits for modulation, demodulation, and filtering. SDRs digitize signals at the antenna and process them with software, enabling a single device to receive virtually any signal type within its frequency range.

SDR technology democratizes signals intelligence by providing flexible, affordable platforms that can be reconfigured through software. The same hardware can decode FM broadcasts, track aircraft via ADS-B, monitor amateur radio, or analyze unknown signals simply by running different software.
SDR Architecture

An SDR consists of an RF front end that filters and amplifies incoming signals, an analog-to-digital converter (ADC) that digitizes the signal, and software that processes the digital data. Key specifications include frequency range, instantaneous bandwidth, and ADC resolution (bit depth).

Higher bandwidth allows capturing more spectrum simultaneously. Greater bit depth provides better dynamic range to distinguish weak signals near strong ones. Frequency range determines what signals you can receive. Each specification involves tradeoffs with cost and complexity.

Dedicated SIGINT distribution with integrated tools

content.title: Security Warning
content.text: Some SDR software applications beacon your location via internet connection or transmit identification data. Always operate collection systems in air-gapped configurations with all network connectivity disabled during sensitive operations. Verify software behavior before deploying for collection.

The RTL-SDR dongle is an entry-level software defined radio providing remarkable capability for its price point. Originally designed as a digital TV receiver, the RTL2832U chipset can be repurposed for wideband reception across VHF and UHF frequencies. At approximately $30, it provides an accessible entry point into SDR and SIGINT.
Specifications

rows: RTL-SDR Blog V3 and V4 models
3.2 MHz possible with some host controllers
Limits dynamic range compared to higher-end SDRs

content.text: Common Applications

items: FM broadcast and amateur radio monitoring
Aviation communications (118-137 MHz) and ADS-B tracking (1090 MHz)
Weather satellite imagery (137 MHz NOAA, 1.7 GHz GOES)
Marine AIS vessel tracking (161-162 MHz)
Trunked radio monitoring (P25, DMR, NXDN)
ISM band device analysis (433 MHz, 915 MHz)
Amateur radio digital modes (APRS, FT8, JS8Call)
General spectrum survey and signal identification

content.text: Limitations

The RTL-SDR's 8-bit ADC provides limited dynamic range compared to higher-end receivers. Strong signals can overload the front end, masking weaker signals of interest. The 2.4 MHz bandwidth restricts simultaneous monitoring to a narrow slice of spectrum. No transmit capability exists. Despite these limitations, the RTL-SDR remains an excellent tool for learning and many practical applications.

content.title: Practical Tip
content.text: Use appropriate filtering for your application. Band-pass filters reduce out-of-band interference that can overload the RTL-SDR's limited dynamic range. An LNA (low noise amplifier) improves sensitivity for weak signals but can worsen overload with strong nearby transmitters. Match your signal chain to the specific monitoring task.

The HackRF One represents a significant step up in capability from entry-level SDRs. Its wide frequency range, transmit capability, and open-source design make it suitable for advanced SIGINT operations and RF research. Created by Great Scott Gadgets, it has become a standard tool in security research communities.
Specifications
SIGINT Applications

Wideband Spectrum Analysis enables surveying large frequency ranges to identify and characterize signals of interest. The 20 MHz bandwidth captures more spectrum simultaneously than narrower devices, speeding initial reconnaissance.

RF Protocol Analysis allows capturing and decoding proprietary wireless protocols. Security researchers use HackRF to analyze IoT devices, wireless sensors, key fobs, and other RF-enabled systems for vulnerability assessment.

Signal Replay and Testing uses the transmit capability to replay captured signals for testing or to understand protocol behavior. This requires appropriate authorization and should only be done in controlled environments.

Antenna switching for automated multi-band monitoring

The KrakenSDR is a coherent 5-channel software-defined radio platform designed specifically for direction finding and passive radar applications. By using five synchronized RTL-SDR receivers with a calibrated antenna array, it enables locating the physical source of RF transmissions from 100 MHz to 1 GHz.
System Components

rows: 5 coherent RTL-SDR receivers with noise source for calibration
5 magnetic mount antennas with calibrated spacing
Raspberry Pi 4/5 with pre-built software image

content.text: Direction Finding Technique

KrakenSDR uses correlative interferometry to determine signal direction. Five antennas arranged in a known geometric pattern receive the same signal. By comparing phase differences between antennas, the software calculates the angle of arrival. The antenna array geometry and spacing must be calibrated for accurate results.

items: Antenna array receives signal simultaneously on all five elements
Noise source calibrates phase relationships between receivers
Software compares phase differences across antenna pairs
Correlative interferometry algorithm computes bearing
Bearing displayed on map overlay in mobile app
Multiple bearings from different locations triangulate transmitter position

content.text: Setup and Operation

items: Burn KrakenSDR DF image to SD card (8GB minimum for Pi4, 16GB for Pi5)
Mount antenna array on vehicle roof with proper spacing using paper templates
Connect antennas to KrakenSDR in correct order (numbering matters)
Power KrakenSDR and Raspberry Pi
Create WiFi hotspot on Android device (SSID: KrakenAndroid, Password: KrakenAndroid)
Access web interface to configure frequency and parameters
Enable noise source calibration before taking bearings
Drive to different positions to collect multiple bearings for triangulation

content.text: Practical Applications

items: Locating interference sources affecting communications
Amateur radio fox hunting and transmitter hunts
Finding unauthorized transmitters or repeaters
Tracking wildlife with radio collars
Educational demonstration of RF direction finding
Locating cellular towers and analyzing coverage

content.title: Accuracy Considerations
content.text: Direction finding accuracy depends on antenna array calibration, multipath reflections, and signal characteristics. Urban environments with buildings cause reflections that produce false bearings. Best results occur in open areas with clear line of sight to the transmitter. Take multiple bearings from different angles and positions to improve location accuracy.

Signal identification is the process of determining what type of transmission you are receiving. This requires recognizing signal characteristics such as bandwidth, modulation type, timing patterns, and frequency behavior. Reference databases and analysis tools help match unknown signals to known types.
Signal Characteristics

rows: Signal type, data rate, modulation complexity
AM, FM, SSB, digital mode, spread spectrum

content.text: Signal Identification Wiki (sigidwiki.com)

The Signal Identification Wiki is a community-maintained database with over 500 cataloged signal types. Each entry includes waterfall images, audio samples, technical parameters, and contextual information. The database is searchable by frequency band, signal type, and various characteristics.

When encountering an unknown signal, capture a waterfall screenshot and audio recording. Compare visual patterns and sound to database entries. Note the frequency, bandwidth, and any timing patterns. The wiki's Unknown Digital and Unknown Analog categories can help identify submissions or find similar unidentified signals.
Artemis Offline Database

Artemis is an open-source application that brings the sigidwiki database offline for field use without internet connectivity. Version 4 (released June 2024) includes substantial improvements and prepares for future machine learning-based identification. The searchable database includes waterfall images and audio samples from the wiki.
Common Signal Types

rows: Narrow (12.5 kHz), two time slots visible

content.title: Pattern Recognition
content.text: Developing signal identification skills requires practice. Spend time monitoring known signals to learn their visual and audio characteristics. When you encounter something unfamiliar, systematically analyze its properties before searching reference databases. Over time, you will recognize common signal types at a glance.

SDR collection operations transform passive monitoring into structured intelligence gathering. This requires planning, systematic execution, accurate documentation, and security awareness. The techniques apply regardless of specific hardware platform.
Spectrum Survey

Begin with a broad spectrum survey to understand the local RF environment. Scan across frequency bands to identify active signals, their characteristics, and temporal patterns. Note which frequencies are busy, which are quiet, and how usage patterns change over time. This baseline informs targeted collection.

items: Define frequency ranges of interest based on intelligence requirements
Configure SDR for maximum bandwidth to scan quickly
Record waterfall displays to capture time-varying patterns
Note signal frequencies, bandwidths, and timing characteristics
Identify signals for detailed analysis or continued monitoring
Document the RF environment as a baseline for detecting changes

content.text: Targeted Collection

After identifying signals of interest, configure for detailed collection. Narrow the frequency range to the target signal. Adjust gain settings to optimize reception. Record raw IQ data for later processing or enable real-time demodulation if the signal type is known.
Traffic Analysis

Even without decoding content, observing transmission patterns provides intelligence. Note when transmissions occur, how long they last, and how traffic volume changes. Correlating RF activity with known events can reveal adversary communication patterns, operating rhythms, and organizational structure.

rows: Activity schedules, shift changes, check-in times

content.text: Geolocation

Multiple SDR receivers at known locations can estimate transmitter position through triangulation or time-difference-of-arrival techniques. The KrakenSDR automates this process. For ad-hoc geolocation, take directional bearings from multiple positions and plot intersections on a map.

content.title: Collection Security
content.text: Protect your collection operations. Use air-gapped systems with no network connectivity during sensitive operations. Disable GPS and location services on collection devices. Be aware that collection positions can potentially be determined if you are transmitting. Maintain OPSEC discipline regarding what you collect and how you use it.

Systematic analysis of the electromagnetic environment enables effective operational planning and threat assessment. The following framework applies to both friendly force emissions (to reduce vulnerability) and adversary emissions (to understand their capabilities and intentions).
Propagation Analysis

items: How far do emissions propagate under current conditions?
How will terrain features affect signal coverage?
What impact does weather have on propagation?
How will reducing transmit power affect detection range?
How will directional antennas concentrate or mask emissions?

content.text: Local RF Environment

items: What frequencies does the local population use?
Can RF usage be adjusted to blend with normal local traffic?
How will your RF usage affect the local environment?
How will adversary RF usage affect your systems?
What unintentional interference risks exist?

content.text: Communications Architecture

items: Are there automatic link establishment or 'always on' systems that emit without user action?
How can units minimize emissions inside threat weapons engagement zones?
What receive-only communications assets exist?
Can forward units operate receive-only while inside threat WEZ?
What is minimum information required to complete critical tasks?

content.text: Threat Assessment

items: What adversary SIGINT capability exists in the area?
What is the likely detection range for your emissions?
How quickly can the adversary geolocate transmitters?
What response capabilities does the adversary possess?
What emissions can the adversary correlate with your activities?

content.text: Signature Management

Every RF emission creates a signature that can be detected, analyzed, and exploited. Manage your electromagnetic signature by minimizing transmission time, reducing power to minimum necessary, using terrain masking, varying emission patterns, and considering timing relative to activities you want to conceal.

content.title: Analysis Framework
content.text: Work through each category methodically before and during operations. The questions form a systematic framework for electromagnetic environment assessment. Answers inform PACE plan development, operating procedures, and risk mitigation measures.

Communications Intelligence (COMINT) focuses on intercepting and analyzing communications between parties. Even when content cannot be decoded, metadata and traffic patterns provide valuable intelligence. COMINT requires understanding common communication systems and their vulnerabilities.
Voice Communications

Analog voice communications (AM, FM, SSB) can be monitored directly with an SDR and appropriate demodulation. Content is immediately accessible. Digital voice modes (P25, DMR, NXDN, D-STAR) require decoding software but many transmissions use unencrypted modes that can be monitored once decoded.
Data Communications

Many data protocols transmit in the clear and can be decoded with appropriate software. ADS-B aircraft tracking, AIS ship tracking, APRS amateur position reports, and pager messages (POCSAG/FLEX) are commonly monitored. IoT devices often use poorly secured protocols that reveal information about their users.
Trunked Radio Systems

Trunked systems dynamically assign channels to talk groups, requiring the monitor to follow control channel assignments. Software like SDRTrunk automates this process, simultaneously monitoring control and voice channels to follow conversations across a trunked system.
Network Identification

Radio networks often transmit identifiers that reveal organizational structure. DMR systems broadcast radio IDs and talk group IDs. P25 systems include NAC (Network Access Code) and talk group information. These identifiers can be cataloged to build understanding of an organization's radio network structure.

content.title: Legal Considerations
content.text: Laws regarding interception of communications vary by jurisdiction. In many countries, receiving unencrypted over-the-air transmissions is legal, but recording or sharing content may be restricted. Cellular communications interception typically requires authorization. Know and comply with applicable laws in your area of operations.

Electronic Intelligence (ELINT) focuses on non-communication electronic emissions, primarily radar systems. By analyzing radar signals, you can determine the type of system, its purpose (surveillance, fire control, missile guidance), and potentially its location. ELINT provides warning of threats and understanding of adversary sensor coverage.
Radar Signal Parameters

rows: Radar type, band (S, C, X, Ku, etc.)

content.text: Common Radar Types

Surveillance radars continuously scan to detect targets over a wide area. They typically use lower frequencies (L, S, C bands) with longer range but lower resolution. Fire control radars track specific targets with narrow beams and higher frequencies (X, Ku bands) for precision. Missile guidance radars illuminate targets for semi-active missiles or track targets for command guidance.
Radar Warning Receiver Concepts

Radar warning receivers (RWR) detect and classify radar emissions to alert crews of threats. The same principles apply to SDR-based ELINT. Captured signals are compared against a library of known emitter parameters to identify the radar type. Changes in received signal characteristics indicate changing threat status.

items: Surveillance radar scanning past your position: periodic illumination
Track radar locked onto your position: continuous illumination
Missile guidance radar active: imminent threat
New emitters appearing: changing tactical situation
Emitters going silent: possible EMCON, repositioning

content.text: SDR Limitations for ELINT

Consumer SDRs have bandwidth and frequency limitations that restrict ELINT capability. Many radar systems operate above 6 GHz, beyond HackRF range. Wideband signals may exceed SDR instantaneous bandwidth. Professional ELINT systems use specialized wideband receivers with extensive signal libraries. SDR-based ELINT is useful for education and limited applications but not comprehensive threat warning.

content.title: Passive Radar
content.text: Passive radar uses existing RF transmissions (FM broadcast, cellular, DVB-T) as illuminators to detect targets without emitting. The KrakenSDR with appropriate software can perform basic passive radar experiments. This technique offers detection capability without revealing your position through emissions.

content.title: Getting Started
content.text: Begin with an RTL-SDR and SDR# or SDR++ software. Monitor known signals (FM broadcast, NOAA weather, amateur repeaters) to learn your equipment. Progress to identifying unknown signals using sigidwiki. Build toward targeted collection operations as your skills develop.
